sections.title: Young-at-heart dentistry for later life
sections.body: Comfort-first dentistry with longer appointments when needed, focused on healthy gums, comfortable dentures or implants, and keeping existing crowns or bridges performing well.
bullets: Prevention-led care that protects natural teeth wherever possible
Gentle support for dry mouth, sensitivity, and changing gum health
Thoughtful planning for dentures, bridges, crowns, and implant options

sections.title: Protect, maintain, and keep every visit comfortable
items: Gum health monitoring with gentle cleaning plans to prevent flare-ups
Dry mouth and sensitivity support matched to your medications and comfort
Maintenance of heavily restored teeth, including crowns and bridges
Checking bite and wear so existing restorations continue to fit and function
Denture comfort assessments across acrylic, chrome, or PEEK designs
Implant and implant-retained denture options discussed when appropriate

sections.title: An unhurried assessment with time for your questions
sections.body: We review your medical history, medications, and day-to-day comfort before examining your teeth, gums, bite, and any existing restorations. You will leave with a clear maintenance plan and options that respect your pace.
bullets: Comfort-first exam with oral cancer screening at every visit
Gum charting, bone support review, and tailored hygiene intervals
Check of crowns, bridges, and fillings for fractures, leakage, or wear
Assessment of dry mouth, sensitivity triggers, and enamel erosion
Review of denture fit, pressure points, and implant health where present
Written plan covering preventive steps and any recommended treatment

sections.title: Care for patients who want comfort and longevity
items: Young-at-heart patients who value calm, longer appointments
Anyone managing dry mouth, sensitivity, or changing gum health
People with crowns, bridges, or heavily restored teeth who want predictable maintenance
Patients with tooth wear or clenching who need bite-friendly plans
Denture wearers seeking better fit, stability, or implant-retained options

sections.title: Step-by-step support designed around comfort
items: Longer or staged appointments if you prefer a slower pace
Comfort measures explained, including breaks and gentle numbing for sensitive areas
Digital photos or scans to baseline wear, gums, and existing restorations
Hygiene approach matched to sensitivity, including airflow-style finishing when suitable
Maintenance plans for crowns, bridges, and implants with clear review intervals
Denture adjustments, relines, or implant-retained options discussed when helpful
sections.strapline: Prevention-first planning keeps treatment conservative and protects the work you already have.

sections.title: Practical steps to keep everything feeling right
items: Soft-bristle brushing and tailored interdental cleaning to protect gums and margins
Support for dry mouth and sensitivity, including hydration tips and clinic-grade products
Care guides for crowns and bridges to reduce chipping or loosened contacts
Night-time protection or bite checks if wear or clenching is present
Denture hygiene, relines, and pressure-point checks to maintain fit
Implant and implant-retained denture reviews with measured hygiene intervals

faqs.question: Do you allow extra time for appointments?
faqs.answer: Yes. We can book longer or staged visits so we can work gently, answer questions, and pace any treatment around your comfort.

faqs.question: What can you do for dry mouth or sensitivity?
faqs.answer: We review medications and triggers, suggest targeted rinses or gels, and adjust cleaning techniques to keep teeth comfortable while protecting enamel.

faqs.question: Do existing crowns or bridges need replacing?
faqs.answer: Not often. We check margins, bite, and supporting teeth. If they remain healthy, we focus on maintenance; if not, we explain repair or replacement options calmly.

faqs.question: Can dentures be made more secure?
faqs.answer: Often yes. We can adjust or reline current dentures, consider chrome or PEEK frameworks, or discuss implant-retained options if suitable.

faqs.question: Are implants safe later in life?
faqs.answer: Suitability depends on gum health, bone support, and medical factors. We assess these carefully and outline alternatives if implants are not high standards option.
